summary: Filter variant calls based on INFO and/or FORMAT annotations

arguments.summary: If true, adds a PG tag to created SAM/BAM/CRAM files.
arguments.name: --add-output-sam-program-record

arguments.summary: If true, adds a command line header line to created VCF files.
arguments.name: --add-output-vcf-command-line

arguments.summary: Set mask at the allele level. This option is not compatible with clustering.
arguments.name: --apply-allele-specific-filters

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: Size of the cloud-only prefetch buffer (in MB; 0 to disable). Defaults to cloudPrefetchBuffer if unset.
arguments.name: --cloud-index-prefetch-buffer

arguments.summary: Size of the cloud-only prefetch buffer (in MB; 0 to disable).
arguments.name: --cloud-prefetch-buffer

arguments.summary: The number of SNPs which make up a cluster. Must be at least 2
arguments.name: --cluster-size

arguments.summary: The window size (in bases) in which to evaluate clustered SNPs
arguments.name: --cluster-window-size
arguments.fulltext: Works together with the --cluster-size argument.  To disable the clustered SNP filter, set this value to less than 1.

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM/CRAM index when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM/CRAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a MD5 digest for any BAM/SAM/CRAM file created
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-md5

arguments.summary: If true, create a VCF index when writing a coordinate-sorted VCF file.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a a MD5 digest any VCF file created.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-md5

arguments.summary: If true, don't cache bam indexes, this will reduce memory requirements but may harm performance if many intervals are specified.  Caching is automatically disabled if there are no intervals specified.
arguments.name: --disable-bam-index-caching

arguments.summary: Read filters to be disabled before analysis
arguments.name: --disable-read-filter

arguments.summary: If specified, do not check the sequence dictionaries from our inputs for compatibility. Use at your own risk!
arguments.name: --disable-sequence-dictionary-validation

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default read filters (WARNING: many tools will not function correctly without their default read filters on)
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-read-filters

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: One or more expressions used with INFO fields to filter
arguments.name: --filter-expression
arguments.fulltext:
VariantFiltration accepts any number of JEXL expressions (so you can have two named filters by using
 --filter-name One --filter-expression "X < 1" --filter-name Two --filter-expression "X > 2").

 It is preferable to use multiple expressions, each specifying an individual filter criteria, to a single
 compound expression that specifies multiple filter criteria.

arguments.summary: Names to use for the list of filters
arguments.name: --filter-name
arguments.fulltext: This name is put in the FILTER field for variants that get filtered.  Note that there must be a 1-to-1 mapping between filter expressions and filter names.

arguments.summary: Filter records NOT in given input mask.
arguments.name: --filter-not-in-mask
arguments.fulltext:
By default, if the --mask argument is used, any variant falling in a mask will be filtered.
 If this argument is used, logic is reversed, and variants falling outside a given mask will be filtered.
 Use case is, for example, if we have an interval list or BED file with "good" sites.
 Note that it is up to the user to adapt the name of the mask to make it clear that the reverse logic was used
 (e.g. if masking against Hapmap, use --mask-name=hapmap for the normal masking and --mask-name=not_hapmap for the reverse masking).

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: One or more expressions used with FORMAT (sample/genotype-level) fields to filter (see documentation guide for more info)
arguments.name: --genotype-filter-expression
arguments.fulltext:
Similar to the INFO field based expressions, but used on the FORMAT (genotype) fields instead.
 VariantFiltration will add the sample-level FT tag to the FORMAT field of filtered samples (this does not affect the record's FILTER tag).
 One can filter normally based on most fields (e.g. "GQ < 5.0"), but the GT (genotype) field is an exception. We have put in convenience
 methods so that one can now filter out hets ("isHet == 1"), refs ("isHomRef == 1"), or homs ("isHomVar == 1"). Also available are
 expressions isCalled, isNoCall, isMixed, and isAvailable, in accordance with the methods of the Genotype object.

 It is preferable to use multiple expressions, each specifying an individual filter criteria, to a single compound expression
 that specifies multiple filter criteria.

arguments.summary: Names to use for the list of sample/genotype filters (must be a 1-to-1 mapping); this name is put in the FILTER field for variants that get filtered
arguments.name: --genotype-filter-name
arguments.fulltext: Similar to the INFO field based expressions, but used on the FORMAT (genotype) fields instead.

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: BAM/SAM/CRAM file containing reads
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: Remove previous filters applied to the VCF
arguments.name: --invalidate-previous-filters
arguments.fulltext: Invalidate previous filters applied to the VariantContext, applying only the filters here

arguments.summary: Invert the selection criteria for --filter-expression
arguments.name: --invert-filter-expression

arguments.summary: Invert the selection criteria for --genotype-filter-expression
arguments.name: --invert-genotype-filter-expression

arguments.summary: Lenient processing of VCF files
arguments.name: --lenient

arguments.summary: Input mask
arguments.name: --mask
arguments.fulltext:
Any variant which overlaps entries from the provided mask file will be filtered. If the user wants logic to be reversed,
 i.e. filter variants that do not overlap with provided mask, then argument --filter-not-in-mask can be used.
 Note that it is up to the user to adapt the name of the mask to make it clear that the reverse logic was used
 (e.g. if masking against Hapmap, use --mask-name=hapmap for the normal masking and --mask-name=not_hapmap for the reverse masking).

arguments.summary: How many bases beyond records from a provided 'mask' should variants be filtered
arguments.name: --mask-extension

arguments.summary: The text to put in the FILTER field if a 'mask' is provided and overlaps with a variant call
arguments.name: --mask-name
arguments.fulltext:
When using the --mask argument, the mask-name will be annotated in the variant record.
 Note that when using the --filter-not-in-mask argument to reverse the masking logic,
 it is up to the user to adapt the name of the mask to make it clear that the reverse logic was used
 (e.g. if masking against Hapmap, use --mask-name=hapmap for the normal masking and --mask-name=not_hapmap for the reverse masking).

arguments.summary: If non-zero, partitions VCF output into shards, each containing up to the given number of records.
arguments.name: --max-variants-per-shard

arguments.summary: When evaluating the JEXL expressions, missing values should be considered failing the expression
arguments.name: --missing-values-evaluate-as-failing
arguments.fulltext:
By default, if JEXL cannot evaluate your expression for a particular record because one of the annotations is not present, the whole expression evaluates as PASSing.
 Use this argument to have it evaluate as failing filters instead for these cases.

arguments.summary: File to which variants should be written
arguments.name: --output

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Read filters to be applied before analysis
arguments.name: --read-filter

arguments.summary: Indices to use for the read inputs. If specified, an index must be provided for every read input and in the same order as the read inputs. If this argument is not specified, the path to the index for each input will be inferred automatically.
arguments.name: --read-index

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM/BAM/CRAM/SRA files read by this program.  The default stringency value SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --read-validation-stringency

arguments.summary: Reference sequence
arguments.name: --reference

arguments.summary: Output traversal statistics every time this many seconds elapse
arguments.name: --seconds-between-progress-updates

arguments.summary: Use the given sequence dictionary as the master/canonical sequence dictionary.  Must be a .dict file.
arguments.name: --sequence-dictionary

arguments.summary: Set filtered genotypes to no-call
arguments.name: --set-filtered-genotype-to-no-call
arguments.fulltext: If this argument is provided, set filtered genotypes to no-call (./.).

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: If true, don't emit genotype fields when writing vcf file output.
arguments.name: --sites-only-vcf-output

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: A VCF file containing variants
arguments.name: --variant

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
Filter variant calls based on INFO and/or FORMAT annotations

This tool is designed for hard-filtering variant calls based on certain criteria. Records are hard-filtered by changing the value in the FILTER field to something other than PASS. Filtered records will be preserved in the output unless their removal is requested in the command line.

Inputs

  • A VCF of variant calls to filter.
  • One or more filtering expressions and corresponding filter names.

Output

A filtered VCF in which passing variants are annotated as PASS and failing variants are annotated with the name(s) of the filter(s) they failed.

Usage example

   gatk VariantFiltration \
   -R reference.fasta \
   -V input.vcf.gz \
   -O output.vcf.gz \
   --filter-name "my_filter1" \
   --filter-expression "AB < 0.2" \
   --filter-name "my_filter2" \
   --filter-expression "MQ0 > 50"

Note

Composing filtering expressions can range from very simple to extremely complicated depending on what you're trying to do.

Compound expressions (ones that specify multiple conditions connected by &&, AND, ||, or OR, and reference multiple attributes) require special consideration. By default, variants that are missing one or more of the attributes referenced in a compound expression are treated as PASS for the entire expression, even if the variant would satisfy the filter criteria for another part of the expression. This can lead to unexpected results if any of the attributes referenced in a compound expression are present for some variants, but missing for others.

It is strongly recommended that such expressions be provided as individual arguments, each referencing a single attribute and specifying a single criteria. This ensures that all of the individual expression are applied to each variant, even if a given variant is missing values for some of the expression conditions.

As an example, multiple individual expressions provided like this: 

   gatk VariantFiltration \
   -R reference.fasta \
   -V input.vcf.gz \
   -O output.vcf.gz \
   --filter-name "my_filter1" \
   --filter-expression "AB < 0.2" \
   --filter-name "my_filter2" \
   --filter-expression "MQ0 > 50"
are preferable to a single compound expression such as this: 
    gatk VariantFiltration \
    -R reference.fasta \
    -V input.vcf.gz \
    -O output.vcf.gz \
    --filter-name "my_filter" \
    --filter-expression "AB < 0.2 || MQ0 > 50"
See this article about using JEXL expressions for more information.
name: VariantFiltration
